franchise.name: DC Franchise Database
franchise.description: Total Drama franchise player statistics and performance data

players.name: Alejandro
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Alejandro played the season like a slow squeeze: build trust, collect options, then tighten the numbers.  He found an early idol and used it as leverage, not a crutch. With 3 immunity wins and 4 total challenge wins, he always had a second path to safety when votes got messy, and he reached the end as the most complete résumé on paper.  The backbone of the run was an unbreakable link with Trent.In the finale, he fell just short—losing to Lindsay 5–4 after a season of control that never quite turned into a title (Result: runner-up; 2nd).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Alejandro treated Season 2 on the Screaming Gaffers like a control puzzle: read the room, win when necessary, and keep danger pointed elsewhere. Ezekiel’s merge idol play protected him at the perfect moment and opened a runway into the endgame. He reached Final Tribal as the season’s most strategically-feared finalist, but finished runner-up to Duncan.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Returning for Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Alejandro finally cashed in the crown after two straight runner-up finishes. Starting on Yellow → Red → Green → Campers, he navigated the swaps without losing his grip, then hit the endgame with back‑to‑back immunity wins (Episodes 7–8). His résumé was sealed at Final 4 with a fire‑making win over Gwen, and he survived the chaos of two public meltdowns (Episodes 10 and 14) long enough to reach Final Tribal Council. Result: Alejandro won Season 4.

players.name: Amy
players.story: Introduced on Rescue Island (Season 5), Amy weaponized the Amy/Samey feud to keep the tribe polarized, often becoming the swing point whenever the vote turned into chaos. She survived into the late game despite regular blowback (3 votes against) and even burned her Shot in the Dark at a key Tribal. Her run ended in Episode 11 when advantage/idol dynamics voided key votes and the numbers finally converged on her (Result: Amy eliminated, 2–1 (with 2 Dave votes voided)).

players.name: Anne Maria

notes: Gave extra vote to Jo from EoE

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Anne Maria played loud, fearless, and constantly in the vote’s orbit—especially once the Mike feud escalated from annoyance to obsession. They survived the midgame with grit and even forced the endgame into advantage math, but the final stretch demanded colder decisions. In Episode 12, Cameron chose the alliance over their unbreakable bond, and an idol/voided vote turned the margin into 4–1* vote (idol cancelled 1) (Result: voted out; 5th, 6th juror).

Betrayed by unbreakable partner Cameron in S3. Wasted idol on Zoey in S4 Episode 1, leading to early elimination.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
In Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Anne Maria delivered one of the most chaotic short runs imaginable. She found an idol—then spectacularly wasted it on Zoey in a round where Zoey received zero votes, turning a power moment into a punchline. Even after leaving, she still affected the game by sending an extra vote to Jo from the Edge. Result: Anne Maria finished 16th.

players.name: B
players.story: On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), B started on the Toxic Rats and played the most dangerous early game: quiet competence. The moment the Rats began thinking about who could beat them later, B's calm reads and steady value turned into “future threat.” The majority didn’t wait—B was clipped in Episode 3 (Result: voted out 6–1 vote; 14th).

players.name: Beardo
players.story: On Season 5’s pre-merge chaos, Beardo leaned into a low-profile social game and tried to stabilize early bonds, but never shook the perception of being expendable in a numbers crunch. With limited challenge impact and the tribe constantly scrambling around twists, he became the path-of-least-resistance boot. He was eliminated in Episode 3 in a vote where very few ballots actually counted (Beardo eliminated, 1–0 (effective)).

players.name: Beth

notes: Sent to RI on opening rocks; eliminated Episode 3 duel

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Beth lived in the danger zone and still refused to leave. She absorbed an absurd amount of heat (22 votes against) and kept reappearing after every Tribal like the story reset itself. Her run wasn’t about immunity or idols—it was about surviving the social fallout of a tribe that kept trying to clean house—she even cracked the Mystery Box by finding its key, and she survived a Safety Without Power tribal when the vote was turning ugly. When the endgame finally tightened, the numbers converged and her luck ran out, but she left with one of the season’s grittiest résumés (Result: eliminated; 5th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Beth’s Season 2 on the Screaming Gaffers was powered by connection — especially the Beth/Lindsay duo — and by staying composed while bigger egos fought for control. She made the deep run by being included in plans without being the face of them, even as idols and revotes forced constant improvisation. Her game ended one step short of the finale in a messy split vote (Beth eliminated at Final Four, 2–1–1).

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Beth came in as a known quantity—and the opener immediately turned into a chaotic, multi-split Tribal where the vote fractured in every direction. When the dust settled, Beth was the one sent to Redemption Island off a rock draw, leaving her no runway to build alliances. She battled for a second life, but her story ended in Episode 3 when she lost the duel, locking in a brutal early exit. (Result: rock draw → Redemption, eliminated in Episode 3 duel; 19th.)

players.name: Blaineley
players.story:
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S5, Blaineley’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 8th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Blaineley approached the game like a producer running a set—paired with Kelly, she managed alliances as brands and treated the merge like damage control. That posture carried her deep, but it also made her the obvious cut once the endgame needed pliable numbers instead of ‘managers.’ In Episode 15, she was voted out 4–1, ending a surprisingly strong late-game run. (Result: voted out Episode 15, 4–1; 6th.)

players.name: Brick
players.story: Debuting on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Brick played the loyal-soldier archetype on the Mutant Maggots—strong in challenges, reliable in alliances, and usually voting with the ‘right’ side. But this season punished predictability. A fractured Tribal turned into a multi-way tally, and Brick was the one the minority could actually land on. The blindside hit in Episode 8 (Result: voted out 5–2–2 vote; 9th, 2nd juror).

players.name: Bridgette
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Bridgette somehow turned 'permanent target' into a deep run. She was hammered with votes all season (20 total against), but kept answering with performance—4 immunity wins and 5 total challenge wins forced the tribe to keep her around even when they didn’t want to.  She also found an idol and stayed fearless about holding it for the right moment. The Safety Without Power twist (Ep 22) became her lifeline—she used it to dodge a vote that was finally ready to land. The endgame was built around unbreakable ties with Trent and Alejandro. She finally fell just one step from the endgame, leaving as a battle-tested juror and the season’s toughest out (Result: eliminated; 3rd).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Returning for Season 2 on Killer Grips, Bridgette tried to steady the tribe’s mood after the premiere, but the first vote snapped into a tight numbers battle driven by Heather’s push and early fear of "big" names. With no one willing to take a risk on a major target yet, Bridgette became the consensus compromise and was cut immediately (Result: Bridgette eliminated, 4–3).

players.name: Brody

notes: Voted out Episode 14 (4–2) after earlier swap boot to RI
keyMoments: Returned from RI at merge with clue
Cut 4–2 as final push against Surfers momentum
Takes 2 votes in Ep1 as early threat ping
Meltdown after swap leads to 5–1 boot

players.story:
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Brody was the season’s endurance monster—paired with Geoff, he absorbed heat and still kept moving forward. He even survived an earlier trip through the swap/Redemption machinery, returning to the game with a target that never truly faded. By Episode 14, the merge needed a clean break from the ‘can’t kill him’ narrative and Brody was voted out 4–2. (Result: voted out Episode 14, 4–2; 7th.)

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Physically useful but targeted for a meltdown on a sacrifice tribe.

players.name: Cameron
players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Cameron operated as the season’s cerebral pivot—building structure early, keeping options open as tribes shifted, and saving power for the exact moment it would matter. Their signature move came with the clock at zero: in Episode 12, Cameron played the last-possible idol on themself, cancelled the only vote against them, and then voted out Anne Maria—breaking an unbreakable bond on purpose to lock in the finale. At Final Tribal, Cameron earned None and finished 3rd, but their vote became the swing factor in a historic 3–3–1 split before the cast tiebreaker crowned Emma.

Strategic mastermind who made brutal move voting out unbreakable partner Anne Maria in S3. Strong strategic player across both seasons.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
In Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Cameron played the classic “quiet glue” game—rarely the loudest voice, but constantly in the numbers. He began on Red → Yellow → Red → Campers and repeatedly re‑integrated after swaps, anchoring what became the core of the Red alliance. At Final 5, Scott’s endgame squeeze snapped shut and Cameron was cut 2–0 before he could argue his case at the end. Result: Cameron finished 5th.

players.name: Cody

seasonDetails.gameplayStyle: Social connector with clutch advantage timing
keyMoments: Finds Legacy Advantage in Ep1; becomes early ‘value holder’
Finds Campers idol late and plays it in F5 advantage dump

players.story:
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Cody spent the pre-merge trying to stay useful without becoming a target—a tough balance on a tribe full of big personalities. He nearly survived the squeeze, but the vote that ended him was decided by a single flip: Leshawna changed sides, turning a close night into a 6–5 send-off. It’s the kind of elimination that haunts a season—because one relationship, one conversation, one minute earlier could’ve rewritten everything (Result: eliminated 6–5; 19th).

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Connected, low-agro operator who survived early heat with Legacy Advantage gravity; found a late idol and timed protections at F5.

players.name: Courtney
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Courtney tried to run camp like a spreadsheet—then reality punched holes in the plan. Her season was defined by control attempts, blowups, and the whiplash that followed: every time she stabilized, another meltdown reopened the target. She survived long enough to reach the jury phase, but the tribe eventually decided the drama wasn’t worth the risk and cut her before she could reset again (Result: eliminated; 9th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Courtney’s Season 2 run on the Screaming Gaffers spiraled fast: the harder she tried to impose structure, the more the room treated her as a liability. Once trust cracked, she stopped being a leader and became the compromise. She was voted out in a tight decision (Courtney voted out, 3–2).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Edge of Extinction (Season 4) was a rough spiral for Courtney. After the Yellow → Red → Campers swap, she unraveled in a round remembered as “triple vote chaos,” burned her extra vote, and couldn’t recover once the revote hit. Result: Courtney was eliminated 4–2 on the Episode 5 Part 2 revote (14th place).

players.name: Crimson
players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Debuting on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Crimson landed on the Mutant Maggots and immediately fell outside the tribe’s first power structure. With alliances forming fast and patience even faster, small frictions became fatal—Crimson was tagged as the easiest opening target before any real counterplay could develop. Episode 1 ended with Crimson as the season’s first blood (Result: voted out 7–1 vote; 16th).

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S3, Crimson’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 16th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Crimson entered as one half of the Goth duo with Ennui, but her game ended almost immediately: she was medically evacuated in Episode 1, instantly turning their pair into a solo run and forcing the tribe to re-map alliances without her. (Result: Crimson evacuated, 20th.)

players.name: Dakota
players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Introduced on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Dakota became instant television on the Toxic Rats—flashy, emotional, and always one scene away from being the episode’s headline. But fandom doesn’t protect you at Tribal. When the vote fractured into a messy pile-up, Dakota caught the stray numbers and became the casualty of a 3–1–1 vote (Fan Favorite) in Episode 5 (Result: voted out; 12th, Fan Favorite).

Fan Favorite winner in S3 despite pre-merge exit. First boot in S4, became first and only person to quit Edge of Extinction.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Dakota’s Edge of Extinction (Season 4) stint was the fastest—and the strangest. She became the first boot in Episode 1 (7–2), landed on the Edge, and then made franchise history as the only player to quit the twist outright. Result: Dakota placed 18th after leaving the Edge at Episode 6.

players.name: Dave
players.story: Dave was a central strategic connector for the Lulu side of Season 5, mixing steady positioning with real challenge value (2 wins, including 1 immunity). In the late game he survived a critical Tribal by playing Shot in the Dark successfully, but the next wave of idol chaos flipped the math against him. He was eliminated in Episode 12 when a 3–3 vote became a clean boot after idol cancellation (Result: Dave eliminated, 3–0 effective (3–3 on paper with idol cancellation)).

players.name: Dawn
players.story: On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Dawn came in on the Toxic Rats with a reputation for reading people—soft-spoken, observant, and socially disarming. As alliances hardened, that perception started to look like danger: if Dawn can see through you, they can expose you. When the majority needed a clean, consensus boot, Dawn became the pick in Episode 9 (Result: voted out 5–3 vote; 8th, 3rd juror).

players.name: DJ
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), DJ was the kind of player everyone loves—and that’s exactly what made him dangerous. By Episode 3, the vote pile was massive (9 votes against), a sign that the tribe wanted the ‘heart’ out before it turned into the center of the game. He didn’t lose a duel; he lost to fear of what he could become if he reached the merge with that much goodwill (Result: eliminated; 22nd).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
DJ’s Season 2 run on Killer Grips was his deepest, steadiest showing: fewer blowups, stronger bonds, and survival through an idol-heavy midgame. He reached Final Five as the "safe" number for multiple sides — and that’s exactly why he became expendable. He was voted out just before the endgame (DJ eliminated at Final Five, 4–1).

players.name: Duncan
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Duncan ran early days on intimidation and loyalty—an alpha approach that works until people get sick of living under it.  He found an idol, but it couldn’t stop the merge math from catching up. His exit was clean and decisive: a 5–3 vote where the majority chose long-term peace over short-term protection. It wasn’t a collapse; it was the moment the cast decided they’d rather risk the unknown than keep letting him set the temperature (Result: eliminated; 14th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Duncan’s Season 2 championship run on the Screaming Gaffers was built on durability: survive the ugliest feuds, keep options open, and stay standing when plans collapse. He outlasted the idol-driven chaos and entered the finale with the clearest case for pressure management and endgame positioning. The jury agreed, crowning him in a 5–1–1 finish (Duncan wins Season 2).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Returning for Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Duncan walked in with a winner’s target and spent the season scrapping for inches. He survived into the merge phase before becoming the consensus boot in a tense 3–2–1 split, exiting at Episode 12 as the endgame tightened. Even on the jury, he left his stamp by casting the lone Final Tribal vote for Scott. Result: Duncan placed 7th.

players.name: Dwayne

keyMoments: Cut as the merge overlap boot

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Dwayne opened on the Mutant Maggots as the camp glue—helpful, friendly, and rarely the loudest voice. That made them perfect jury material once the merge arrived and the game needed cleaner lines. When the majority tightened and started trimming flexible middle pieces, Dwayne became the first juror in Episode 7 (Result: voted out 5–3–2 vote (1st juror); 10th, 1st juror).

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S3, Dwayne’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 10th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Dwayne played as the anxious dad half of the Dwayne–Junior pair, constantly trying to keep the target off his son while the tribe spiraled into pair politics. He survived the early turbulence, but the merge format turned brutal: at the Episode 9 merge vote, a fractured field produced a 4–3–3–1 outcome—and Dwayne was the one name that stuck. Worse, the twist removed Redemption as a safety net; he was eliminated on the spot with no duel, no return path. (Result: direct merge boot, 4–3–3–1; 11th.)

players.name: Ella
players.story: Ella’s Rescue Island run was defined by pure social warmth and early connection-building, but that visibility made her an easy name when the tribe needed a clean vote. With the game already drifting toward advantage paranoia, she couldn’t find a shield in time. She was eliminated in Episode 2 on a tight pre-merge vote (Ella eliminated, 2–1).

players.name: Emma

notes: Re-entry penalty used on Anne Maria
Rock-draw casualty Episode 10; later eliminated on RI
keyMoments: Lost via rocks in a deadlock

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Debuting on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Emma won by doing something scarier than idol fireworks: staying loyal, staying likable, and striking only when the numbers demanded it. From the Toxic Rats into the merged Campers, Emma kept their social credit spotless—so spotless that they reached the endgame with zero votes against before the Final 4. In the tightest finish of the season, Emma claimed the crown via a None in Episode 13 (Result: champion; 1st).

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S3 and S4, Emma’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 1th.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Coming in as a previous winner, Emma entered Edge of Extinction (Season 4) with a bullseye already painted. The tribe never gave her time to settle: she was cut in Episode 2 by a 5–3 vote as the cast chose safety over letting a champion breathe. Result: Emma finished 17th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Emma entered with Kitty as the sister pair built for the merge—tight bond, clear reads, and a willingness to play hard when needed. She even grabbed the first merge immunity, but her season turned into a personal war: the Emma–Ryan feud kept poisoning coalition talks until the merge vote finally snapped into a deadlock. In Episode 10, Emma was the rock-draw casualty—one of the most brutal ‘the game doesn’t care’ exits of the franchise—and she was later finished off on Redemption.Emma finished 10th. (Result: rocks → RI; 10th.)

players.name: Ennui

notes: Voted out Episode 3 (6–3) to RI; later eliminated

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Ennui started tethered to Crimson—and then had to play alone the moment Crimson was pulled from the game. With the pair advantage gone, Ennui became an easy consensus name once the tribes needed “safe” targets, taking the fall in Episode 3 on a 6–3 vote and being sent to Redemption. The comeback never materialized, and he was eliminated on the island soon after. (Result: voted out to RI, 16th.)

players.name: Eva
players.story: Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Eva arrived as pure volatility—strength, pride, and a fuse that never looked long. She fought her way through the opening stretch, but the tribe eventually chose stability: a 6–4 vote that removed the person most likely to explode the plan the moment it formed. In a season obsessed with numbers, she was the one player who could make numbers meaningless—and that’s why they took the shot (Result: eliminated; 21st).

players.name: Ezekiel

notes: Legendary idol play on Alejandro at merge
Lost fire-making to Alejandro at F4

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Ezekiel was the definition of 'scrappy survives.' He found 2 idols over the season and kept slipping through danger windows with just enough information and just enough nerve. Even without a big challenge résumé (1 total wins), he played the advantage game like a veteran and made it all the way to Final 4. There, the season ended in the most brutal way possible: fire-making, where he lost to Alejandro and watched the title disappear in smoke (Result: fire-making loss; 4th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Ezekiel’s Season 2 on Killer Grips became legendary at the merge when his idol play protected Alejandro and erased a pile of votes, rewiring the entire post-merge. That move turned him into a kingmaker — and a must-remove threat. He was taken out at Final 6 once the cast agreed the window to beat him was closing (Ezekiel voted out, 4–2).

players.name: Geoff

notes: Voted out Episode 16 (4–1) after returning from RI
keyMoments: Anchored early Galang core with Mickey/Ryan
Cut 4–1 as the late jury threat

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Geoff played the classic social shield game—make everyone laugh, keep everyone comfortable, and hope the vote stays elsewhere. It worked… until the tribe decided comfort was a threat. With 13 votes against and a lopsided 7–2 boot, his exit reads like a warning: when your social capital is *too* obvious, the easiest move is to cash you out before the merge chaos (Result: eliminated; 20th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Geoff’s Edge of Extinction (Season 4) story was a full roller‑coaster: voted out once, refused to disappear, and then voted out again. He was sent to the Edge by Zoey at Episode 10, battled back by winning the Episode 13 return challenge, and was immediately re‑eliminated in the very same episode—again with Zoey steering the outcome. Result: Geoff finished 6th after an all‑time comeback attempt.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Geoff leaned hard into the ‘good vibes’ social game—keeping people close through the swap and into the merge while trying to stay out of the crossfire. It worked… until the merge finally snapped into a tense 3–2–1 split that sent him to Redemption Island. Geoff refused to fade, fought his way back into the game in Episode 16, and then got hit with the franchise’s harshest reality check: the tribe immediately voted him out again, 4–1, because his comeback was simply too dangerous to leave alive. (Result: voted out 3–2–1 → Redemption → returned Ep16 → voted out 4–1; 5th.)

players.name: Gwen
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Gwen survived the early chaos by keeping her circle small and her threat level lower than her talent. But Season 1’s tribe swap punished solitary games: a 5–4 vote where one new connection mattered more than everything she’d built before. She didn’t get outplayed in a duel—she got caught in the first real math problem of the season, and the numbers chose her (Result: tribe-swap casualty; 16th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Gwen’s Season 2 on the Screaming Gaffers was played from the edges: selective trust, sharp reads, and constant threat-management. A deadlocked Tribal forced a re-vote around her, showing how evenly the power split had become. She ultimately went out in the season’s double-elimination sequence (Gwen finishes 8th), where tempo beat nuance.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Edge of Extinction (Season 4) turned Gwen into an endgame machine. After surviving the Yellow → Red → Campers shuffle, she caught fire late with four straight immunity wins (Episodes 11–14), a franchise record that forced everyone to plan around her. With the finale in sight, the run ended at the final hurdle when Alejandro beat her at fire‑making. Result: Gwen was eliminated at Final 4.

players.name: Harold
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Harold kept believing he could ‘wait for the perfect moment’—even when the perfect moment was screaming at him. He held an idol and still walked into a 4–3–2 vote without playing it, one of the season’s biggest self-inflicted tragedies. His strategic instincts were real, but the timing wasn’t, and Season 1 doesn’t forgive hesitation when the room is splitting (Result: eliminated with idol in pocket; 17th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
On Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Harold’s run revolved around one fragile lifeline: an “unbreakable” bond with Gwen that eventually collapsed under pressure. He survived a messy round that needed a revote, but the cracks widened after a Cameron betrayal and he was finally clipped 3–2 at Final 8. Result: Harold finished 8th.

players.name: Heather

notes: Lost to Owen on Exile Beach

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Heather treated the game like a knife fight with a smile. She found 2 idols and used them to keep the tribe guessing, then pulled off the season’s most talked-about rescue—saving Bridgette when the vote was ready to bury her. Even with 10 votes against, she kept landing on her feet until the game forced her into Exile Beach. There, Owen beat her in the return battle and the villain finally ran out of exits (Result: Exile loss; 8th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Heather returned on Killer Grips doing what she does best: driving targets, steering conversations, and keeping bigger flames lit elsewhere. But her influence was too visible, and once the cast had a clear opening they removed the proven manipulator before she could pivot again. She was voted out decisively in the midgame (Heather eliminated, 7–2).

Heather tried to rebuild her old‑school control in Edge of Extinction (Season 4), but the season punished anyone who looked comfortable. Her early Yellow structure dissolved, fights erupted, and the target snapped back onto her. Result: Heather was eliminated 3–2 in Episode 5 (15th place).

players.name: Izzy
players.story: Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Izzy turned every day into a curveball—fun, chaotic, and impossible to predict. That chaos bought her time until the tribe swap, when unpredictability stops being entertainment and starts being liability. In a razor-thin 5–4, the new majority cut the wild card before she could rewrite the deck again (Result: tribe-swap casualty; 18th).

players.name: Jacques

keyMoments: Engineered Kitty’s idol burn at merge
Won 4 immunities to steer late votes
Chose the Final 4 tie path that sent Kelly out

notes: Quit at Final 4 after winning immunity; meltdown ends game.
keyMoments: Builds Naale core, then bonds with Shawn to flip Devin (Ep7)
Wins 5 immunities; safe through late merge
F4 immunity win followed by quit

players.story:
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Jacques turned the Ice Dancers pairing with Josee into a masterclass in controlled threat management. While louder duos burned trust and idols, he stayed ‘useful’—competent in challenges, calm in camp, and quietly steering the merge vote map by weaponizing other people’s feuds. He survived the season’s chaos points (tribe re-draw, Redemption returns, rock-draw fallout) and arrived at the end with the cleanest résumé left. In the finale, the jury didn’t debate—they crowned him in a 7–1–0 landslide. (Result: Season 6 champion, 1st.)

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Hyper-competent strategist and challenge beast who built cross-tribe ties; zero votes all season but exits via quit at F4.

players.name: Jasmine

keyMoments: Named early but avoided pre-merge danger

players.story:
Jasmine brought a steady, survival-first presence to the early Belo/Reba chaos, attempting to keep the tribe focused while smaller rivalries pulled votes in different directions. Without advantages or a dominant alliance to lock her in, she became a convenient compromise boot once numbers got messy. She exited in Episode 5 (Jasmine eliminated, 2–1).

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Respected voice and steady competitor; became the merge peace-offering boot.

players.name: Jay

keyMoments: Sat in the Final 4 tie that booted Kelly

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Jay was the loyal half of the Jay–Mickey duo, surviving by staying attached to the strongest protection available and never panicking when the vote map shifted. He rode through tribe re-draws, merge chaos, and the rock-round without becoming the primary target, then slipped into the endgame as the safest option to sit next to. He reached Final Tribal—but with zero jury votes, his story became the classic ‘made it there, didn’t own it’ finish. (Result: finalist, 3rd.)

players.name: Jo

advantages: Extra vote from Anne Maria (EoE), used Ep 8

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Introduced on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Jo tried to run the Mutant Maggots through intimidation and control—pushing the tribe to win while collecting enemies at the same time. It worked until it didn’t. By the merge, the social bill came due: four extreme hatred relationships and zero safe landing spots. The pile-on finally happened in Episode 10 (Result: voted out 4–3 vote; 7th, 4th juror).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Most hated player with 4 EXTREME HATRED relationships. FAN FAVORITE winner in S4 for chaotic entertainment value.

Edge of Extinction (Season 4) was pure friction for Jo: she collected rivals like trophies and never stopped pushing the game into confrontation.  She even received an extra vote from the Edge and cashed it at Episode 8. At Final 9, the blowback finally landed—after a 5–3 revote, the season’s most combustible personality hit the jury. Result: Jo placed 10th.

players.name: Josee
players.story:
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S5, Josee’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 13th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Josee and Jacques arrived with a reputation for aggression—and the cast treated them like a loaded weapon. After surviving the first wave, Josee became the clean ‘separate the Ice Dancers’ target: she was voted out in Episode 5 on a decisive 6–1 and sent to Redemption, where she was eventually eliminated. Her arc was a reminder that intimidation can win challenges, but it also paints a target you can’t always outrun. (Result: voted out 6–1 → RI; 12th.)

players.name: Junior

notes: Voted out Episode 4 (6–2) to RI; later eliminated on RI

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Junior was the vulnerable half of the father–son duo with Dwayne, forcing the pair to play from a defensive posture all pre-merge. When the tribe wanted a ‘safe’ vote that wouldn’t trigger immediate retaliation, Junior was the compromise: he was voted out in Episode 4 (6–2) and shipped to Redemption. He fought to stay alive on the island, but couldn’t convert it into a return. (Result: voted out 6–2 → RI; 15th.)

players.name: Justin

notes: First juror after Ezekiel's idol play
Found idol early but didn't play it

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Justin walked in thinking charm was enough to coast.  He even found an early idol—then left with it still in his pocket. The problem was that Season 1 didn’t reward ‘liked’—it rewarded *locked-in numbers*, and he never secured them. As the first boot, he became the season’s opening statement: popularity is fragile, and if the tribe wants an easy night, the pretty target goes first (Result: first boot; 24th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Justin played Season 2 on Killer Grips by hovering near power without becoming the headline — until the merge chaos rewrote everything. Ezekiel’s idol play nuked the original plan and left Justin as the first exposed piece when the board reset. With multiple votes voided and no shields left, the tribe took the clean shot and made him the first juror (Justin voted out, 4–0).

players.name: Katie
players.story: Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Katie came in as part of MAPLV—tight, social, and dangerous in numbers. She even found the Killer Bass idol, but Season 1 punished hesitation: the Tribal that ended her run was a mess of split votes and voided plans (5–3–3*–1). In the chaos, the tribe finally found a clean landing spot—and it was her—ending a run that was louder politically than the placement suggests (Result: eliminated; 12th).

players.name: Kelly

notes: Eliminated Final 4 (2–2 tie, 1–1 revote, lost fire-making)
keyMoments: Found and correctly played Tadhana idol at swap

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Kelly played the ‘tough mom’ half of her duo with Blaineley—steady, protective, and far more strategic than people wanted to admit. Her idol timing helped shape the midgame (including the Episode 7 swing that took out Mary), and she navigated all the way to the Final 4. There, the season’s chaos returned one last time: a 2–2 tie, a 1–1 revote, and then fire-making—where she fell just short of the finale. (Result: Final 4 fire-making loss; 4th.)

players.name: Kitty

notes: Voted out Episode 11 (3–2–2–1–1) to RI (idol previously burned on Jacques)
keyMoments: Played idol on Jacques at merge
Sent to RI in a 5-way split vote

notes: Post-idol execution 5–3–3 after legendary double-idol firewall.
keyMoments: Finds Naale idol then Lawa idol
Ep9 ‘idol firewall’: cancels 8 votes on herself and shields Scott; Pete goes

players.story:
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Kitty played heart-first beside Emma, using social warmth to keep their duo insulated while bigger pairs self-destructed. But loyalty came with a price: she burned her idol earlier trying to protect/shape the power structure, and once the merge chaos hit, she was left exposed. In Episode 11, a messy multi-target Tribal finally converged and Kitty was voted out 3–2–2–1–1, sent to Redemption before her eventual elimination. (Result: voted out 3–2–2–1–1 → RI; 9th.)

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Season’s early hidden boss: held two idols at once, built webs across tribes; saved herself and Scott in a single tribal before being finished the next round.

players.name: Leonard

notes: Voted out Episode 2 (5–3) to RI; eliminated Episode 4

players.story:
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S5, Leonard’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 18th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Leonard tried to turn wizard energy into strategic cover with Tammy, pitching himself as ‘harmless chaos’ while bigger pairs went to war. But in a format where pairs punish weakness fast, the tribe chose stability over spectacle: Leonard was voted out in Episode 2 (5–3) and sent to Redemption. He couldn’t win his way back, and his run ended with an island elimination in Episode 4. (Result: voted out 5–3 → RI; eliminated Episode 4; 18th.)

players.name: Leshawna
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Leshawna was the kind of player who makes everybody feel protected—until they realize she’s the one holding the room together. She won key moments (1 total challenge wins) and built a tight bond with Noah, which kept her insulated while the tribe cannibalized itself. At Final 11, the fear finally caught up: a chaotic 7–3–1–1 split that shows how many people *wanted* her out, even if they couldn’t agree on anything else (Result: eliminated; 11th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Leshawna’s Season 2 on the Screaming Gaffers never had time to ignite. Early clashes and a lack of reliable protection left her exposed once the tribe wanted a clean, low-drama boot. She was sent out as the second elimination in a landslide (Result: Leshawna eliminated, 6–1).

players.name: Lightning

notes: WORST idol play ever (wasted on Emma)

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Lightning hit the beach as raw momentum—an athletic engine on the Toxic Rats who assumed wins would equal safety. Instead, the season answered with chaos. A tied Tribal dragged Lightning into a do-or-die revote, and when relationships shifted at the worst possible moment, the numbers finally turned. Lightning fell in Episode 6 after the 2–2 tie fi 2–2 revote sequence flipped against them (Result: voted out; 11th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Part of TRIPLE IDOL TRIBAL in S4. Worst idol play in S3 (wasted on Emma who got 0 votes).

Lightning hit Edge of Extinction (Season 4) with a physical‑threat reputation, but the cast never let him build real momentum. He was caught in the triple‑idol Tribal (Episode 5 Part 2) and became the first merge boot, leaving on a 9–4 vote before challenges could save him. Result: Lightning finished 13th.

players.name: Lindsay

notes: First boot 6–2–2 on Naale; winner threat + fight with Shawn.
keyMoments: Fight with Shawn becomes consensus fuel

players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Lindsay won by doing the simplest thing in the hardest way: staying universally liked while keeping the target off her back. She never needed an immunity run—her game was relationships and timing, not fireworks—yet she still reached the finale with only 1 vote against. The endgame was built around unbreakable ties with Leshawna, Trent and Alejandro. In the finale, she edged out Alejandro in a 5–4 vote to claim the crown (Result: champion; 1st).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Lindsay’s Season 2 was a social masterclass: she kept multiple relationships alive at once, avoided being the easy consensus name, and rode the Beth partnership without being trapped by it. When chaos hit — idols, revotes, and shifting numbers — she consistently landed on her feet. She reached Final Tribal but lost to Duncan when the jury rewarded endurance over charm (Lindsay loses, 1–5–1).

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Episode 1 casualty after a lasting fight; quiet winner-threat undertone expedited her exit.

players.name: Mary

notes: Idol casualty Episode 7 (Kelly’s idol negated majority)

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Mary played the season like a chess player trapped in a hurricane—always trying to keep information and angles. Paired with Beth, she refused an early swap-to-Redemption option that would have looked loyal but left her powerless, choosing instead to stay in the tribe mix and build a quiet ‘Brainiacs’ lane. That patience bought time… until Episode 7, when an idol/advantage swing (Kelly’s idol) flipped the numbers and Mary became the casualty of a vote that should have gone the other way. (Result: idol-negated majority; Mary voted out, 14th.)

players.name: Max
players.story: Max leaned into a disruptive, chaos-friendly game on Season 5, frequently pulling attention and forcing others to account for worst-case twists. He gained Safety Without Power, which shaped vote calculus even when he couldn’t fully cash it in for long-term security. Eventually the table got tired of the volatility and he was voted out in Episode 8 (Max eliminated, 5–3).

players.name: Mickey

keyMoments: Played idol on Jay at Final 5

players.story:
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
Introduced on Rescue Island (Season 5), Mickey didn’t win by being the loudest—he won by being the safest place for everyone else to stand. He played the season like a pressure valve: never the obvious target, always the option people could live with, and he turned that low-heat positioning into a championship when the endgame punished the bigger egos. (Result: winner; 1st.)

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Mickey came in with a champion’s target but flipped it into camouflage by attaching himself to the cleanest partnership in the game: Mickey + Jay. While the tribe dynamics swung around duos and feuds, Mickey stayed measured—letting other names absorb the damage while he quietly stacked tools. He secured the Galang idol and used it the way winners do: not for fireworks, but for timing. The season’s defining moment was Final 5—when Mickey played his idol on Jay to erase the only path that breaks their duo. That single decision forced the game to reroute around them, bought Mickey the finale, and proved he was still playing one step ahead when it mattered most. At Final Tribal, though, Jacques’ résumé was too sharp to deny: the jury locked in a 7–1–0 vote and Mickey walked away with second place and one jury vote—close enough to touch the crown, but not enough to take it. (Result: finalist, 2nd; lost 7–1–0.)

players.name: Mike
players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Mike started on the Mutant Maggots but quickly became the center of the season’s messiest feud: Mike vs Anne Maria. While others used that chaos as cover, the rivalry kept repainting targets every round. Once the game needed a decisive cut before the endgame, the numbers converged—Mike was voted out in Episode 11 (Result: voted out 4–2 vote; 6th, 5th juror).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
REBUILT unbreakable bond with Zoey in S4. Victim of Sierra's perfect idol play (10 votes cancelled).

In Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Mike became the lightning rod for chaos—nine votes against and a constant target the moment the tribe wanted an easy name. His exit was shaped by advantage dynamics: Sierra’s perfect idol play voided the main plan, and Mike was the only clean option left, leaving 2–0. Result: Mike placed 12th.

players.name: Noah
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Noah tried to weaponize sarcasm into strategy—sharp reads, sharp tongue, and just enough allies to be dangerous. It worked for a while, but his game lived on a knife-edge: 9 votes against and a constant sense that one conversation could flip the room. That’s exactly how he went out—4–3, a one-vote swing that turned ‘clever asset’ into ‘too clever to keep’ overnight (Result: eliminated; 15th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Noah’s Edge of Extinction (Season 4) ended in the season’s messiest flashpoint: the infamous triple‑idol Tribal. He burned his own idol in the chaos, only to see the numbers shift anyway—punished for a late‑game betrayal and sent out 5–4 at Final 9. Result: Noah became a jury voice at 9th place.

players.name: Owen
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Owen was the season’s emotional center—and the season kept testing it. He was sent to Exile, fought his way back into the game, and instantly became a problem again because people *liked* having him around. That goodwill carried him deep even with 6 votes against, but his story ended in the harshest non-vote exit: a medical evacuation in Episode 20, right after proving he could survive the twist stack (Result: med-evac; 7th).

────────

SEASON 2 — Action
────────

SEASON 2 — Action
Owen entered Season 2 on the Screaming Gaffers as social glue — connected to everyone and rarely anyone’s first target. Then Courtney detonated the season’s first big idol moment, voiding a stack of votes and forcing the tribe to improvise on the spot. When the plan collapsed, Owen became the easiest fallback and was voted out third (Owen eliminated, 3rd out).

players.name: Rodney
players.story: Rodney played Season 5 like a classic mid-game grinder: visible, socially active, and constantly trying to grab tools that could flip a vote. He notably secured Knowledge Is Power from a Journey, instantly spiking his threat level even without challenge dominance. Once the tribe decided he was too dangerous to keep around, he was voted out in Episode 7 (Rodney eliminated, 3–1).

players.name: Ryan

notes: Voted out Episode 12 (5–2–1) to Redemption; later eliminated on RI

players.story:
SEASON 5 — Rescue Island
SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
Previously seen in S5, Ryan’s best finish before Blood vs. Water was 3th.

────────

SEASON 6 — Blood vs. Water
On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Ryan and Stephanie were the combustible pair that everyone could feel coming—the kind that wins moments but fractures rooms. Once the merge arrived, his vote-war fallout with Emma became a season-defining crack, turning strategy into a cycle of retaliation. The house eventually chose stability over chaos: Ryan was voted out in Episode 12 (5–2–1) and sent to Redemption, where his run ended. (Result: voted out 5–2–1 → RI; 8th.)

players.name: Sadie
players.story: Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Sadie played the rarest kind of game: invisible but untouchable. She never received a single vote all season, stayed inside MAPLV’s cover, and looked like the perfect ‘take her later’ piece. Then Season 1 reminded everyone it’s a horror movie: a rock draw. One unlucky pull erased a spotless record and sent her out without ever being targeted (Result: rock draw; 13th).

players.name: Sam
players.story: On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Sam began on the Toxic Rats and tried to win by loyalty rather than steering the vote. That loyalty became the storyline when a split Tribal collapsed into the season’s first deadlock. With neither side blinking after the 3–3 tie fi rocks (eliminated) tie, the game went to rocks—and Sam drew the short straw in Episode 4 (Result: eliminated by rock draw; 13th).

players.name: Samey
players.story: Samey’s Season 5 story is the underdog attempt to play her own game while the Amy rivalry kept dragging her into the spotlight. She picked up a Goodwill-style social leverage moment and tried to build safer bonds, but advantage chaos punished anyone without hard protection. In Episode 4, an idol cancelled multiple votes and she was eliminated on an ultra-thin effective count (Result: Samey eliminated 1–0 (effective) after idol cancels 4 votes).

players.name: Scarlett
players.story: Top strategic rank of Season 5 and a late power player, but lost the Final 4 fire-making duel.

players.name: Scott

notes: Perfect idol play at F5 (3 votes cancelled)
Only Duncan voted for him at FTC
Executed at F8 as dangerous swing after duo split.
keyMoments: Forms controlling Naale duo with Shawn
Receives Kitty’s protective idol shield at Ep9

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Introduced on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Scott was the season’s challenge engine—stacking the most wins and setting the pace whenever immunity mattered. They paired that dominance with ruthless timing, including the endgame betrayal of Zoey after an unbreakable bond carried them to the brink. Scott reached Final Tribal with a ‘challenge beast’ résumé, but the jury rewarded loyalty and relationships instead. (Result: Scott lost 3–4–1; runner-up.)

Best player to never win. PERFECT IDOL PLAY after holding for 9 tribals (franchise record). Runner-up in S3, third place in S4.

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Scott came into Edge of Extinction (Season 4) as the franchise’s cleanest “toolbox” player—and proved it. He held an idol through nine consecutive Tribal Councils (a franchise record), then timed a perfect Final 5 play that cancelled three votes and kept his endgame intact. He even knocked out Cameron in a 2–0 decision, but at Final Tribal Council only Duncan rewarded the résumé. Result: Scott placed 3rd.

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Half of the season’s tightest duo with Shawn; targeted repeatedly, saved by Kitty’s idol once, then removed as a swing threat.

players.name: Shawn

notes: Duo with Scott finally cracked 5–4 at F9.
keyMoments: Open war with Kitty across merge

players.story:
Shawn navigated Season 5 with a paranoid-but-prepared mindset, finding a Beware Idol on Belo and briefly holding real leverage at the merge. His risk-taking peaked when he used Shot in the Dark and lost his vote, putting him on the wrong side of the numbers. He was eliminated in Episode 9 (Shawn eliminated, 5–2), but not before becoming a real factor in the season’s advantage economy.

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Early Naale swing with bonds to Devin; later the merge lightning rod and long-running feud with Kitty.

players.name: Sierra
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Sierra played like a walking information leak—always watching, always collecting, always *one step* from overplaying.  She found an idol, but it didn’t buy her the trust she needed. With 13 votes against, she became the ‘safe cut’ whenever the tribe wanted a clean night: no blood feud, just consensus. That’s exactly how it ended in a 6–4 vote—everyone agreeing she was dangerous *later*, so they took the shot *now* (Result: eliminated; 10th).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
Sierra authored the season’s biggest “second life” arc in Edge of Extinction (Season 4). Voted out early, she stayed on the Edge, won the Episode 6 return challenge, and re‑entered with a perfect idol play that wiped seven votes and saved Geoff—instantly rewriting the board. The comeback didn’t last: the heat returned fast, and she was voted out again at Episode 8 after a run fueled by extreme feuds across the cast. Result: Sierra finished 11th after a rare two‑chapter season.

players.name: Sky

notes: Cut at F6 as a threat tethered to Jacques.
keyMoments: Swap survival and integration on Mauhu
Votes on key merge swings (Jasmine, Shawn)

players.story:
Season 5 challenge MVP with 4 total challenge wins and 3 immunities; forced the late-game tempo but fell short in a 3–3 FTC tie.

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Bridge between power lanes pre-merge; later feuded with MacArthur and got clipped as a connected endgame threat.

players.name: Staci
players.story: On Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Staci arrived on the Toxic Rats as pure chaos at the worst possible time: the Rats were in survival mode and wanted stability, not stories. Once the tribe agreed to keep the challenge pieces intact, Staci became the clean ‘noise’ boot. The vote locked in and Staci exited in Episode 2 (Result: voted out 6–2 vote; 15th).

players.name: Stephanie

notes: Voted out Episode 6 (6–1); threw an idol clue into the fire on RI
keyMoments: Burned an idol clue on RI
Voted out 6–1 after conflict with Jacques

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Stephanie came in with Ryan as pure intensity—competitive, confrontational, and always one argument away from a blow-up. That edge kept her relevant early, but in a pairs season it also makes you radioactive: once the tribe needed an easy reset vote, she was cut in Episode 6 on a 6–1. Even on Redemption she stayed on-brand, famously throwing an idol clue into the fire—burning information the way she burned bridges. (Result: voted out 6–1 → RI; 13th.)

players.name: Sugar
players.story: Sugar made one of the deepest runs of Season 5 by surviving constant heat (10 votes against) and leaning into a loud, chaos-driven social style that kept targets rotating. With the endgame dominated by idol-threat management, she repeatedly found herself in the crosshairs as players tried to simplify the board. She was eliminated in Episode 13 in a near-unanimous vote with a cancelled ballot (Sugar eliminated, 4–0 (with 1 Sky vote cancelled)).

players.name: Tammy

notes: Swap to RI in Ep2; eliminated on RI in Episode 5
keyMoments: Voted in twist to RI Day 1

players.story: On Blood vs. Water (Season 6), Tammy entered with Leonard as the season’s most openly ‘out-there’ pair—fun, but rarely trusted. She got hit early by the swap-to-Redemption mechanic in Episode 2, which stranded her away from the main vote map and turned her game into pure survival. Without numbers or protection, she was eliminated on Redemption in Episode 5. (Result: swap → RI, eliminated Episode 5; 17th.)

players.name: Topher
players.story: Topher’s Rescue Island run revolved around risk-reward mechanics: he took on a Beware-style disadvantage, forcing him to manage social fallout while dealing with limited voting power. Without immunity wins or an idol safety net, he became the merge’s stability target. He was eliminated in Episode 7 and became the season’s first juror (Topher eliminated, 5–1 (and becomes 1st juror due to being eliminated from).

players.name: Trent
players.story:
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
SEASON 1 — Cullhouse
Introduced on Screaming Gophers (Season 1), Trent played a steady, alliance-first game—until it turned personal. His partnership network kept him insulated early, but the season’s defining tension was his escalating war with Heather—openly toxic and impossible to hide. He still stacked 2 immunity wins and 3 total challenge wins, looking like a real finals threat, before the game hit a sudden double-elimination. In that snap Tribal, he was clipped 5–2, proving that even solid positioning can vanish in one twist (Result: double-elimination; 6th).

Trent returned on the Screaming Gaffers with relationships everywhere, but also friction brewing — especially with Duncan. As the midgame tightened, his social reach stopped looking harmless and started looking dangerous. He was voted out when the numbers finally converged (Trent voted out, 5–2), setting up the season’s ruthless double-boot stretch.

players.name: Tyler
players.story: Introduced on Killer Bass (Season 1), Tyler tried to sell himself as the challenge engine—then the season labeled him the opposite. After becoming a repeated liability, he was cut in an 8–4 vote, the tribe choosing reliability over potential. His story is the blunt Season 1 lesson: if you can’t deliver in the early team phase, you don’t get to reach the individual game (Result: eliminated; 23rd).

players.name: Zoey

notes: Perfect idol play saved Geoff (7 votes cancelled)
Made finals with zero votes against (1 cancelled)

keyMoments: Lasting fight with Carrie at swap

players.story:
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
SEASON 3 — Revenge of the Island
Debuting on Revenge of the Island (Season 3), Zoey was the social connector on the Mutant Maggots—liked by most, tied into multiple groups, and strong enough in challenges to stay relevant. Their run became defined by trust: the unbreakable bond with Scott carried them deep, even as the endgame turned into betrayal roulette. At the final vote before the Final Tribal Council, Scott pulled the trigger and Zoey was cut in Episode 13 (Result: voted out 3–1; 4th, final juror).

────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
────────

SEASON 4 — Edge of Extinction
UNPRECEDENTED social dominance with 3 unbreakable bonds at once in S4. Lost 6-7 to Alejandro in closest finale ever. Most socially connected player in franchise history.

On Edge of Extinction (Season 4), Zoey delivered a near‑perfect social game. She built an unprecedented web of three “unbreakable bonds” at once, kept her name off the parchment all season (the only vote against her was cancelled), and capped the midgame with a perfect idol play that erased seven votes and saved Geoff. After a key Episode 8 flip and back‑to‑back immunities late (Episodes 11–12), she reached Final Tribal Council—but fell just short. Result: Zoey finished runner‑up.

────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
────────

SEASON 7 — Unknown
Returnee social stabilizer targeted in a numbers lock after a volatile swap.

players.name: Carrie

keyMoments: Survives early Lawa turbulence and integrates
Co-founds Lawa #3 (with Cody/MacArthur) and drives Zoey boot at swap
Wins merge immunity (Ep11) and guides calm boot on Laurie
Uses Vote Steal at F5 to delete Tom’s outs

players.story: Social hub protected by tight bonds; wielded a Vote Steal at F5 to lock path to the finals.

players.name: Devin

notes: Taken out 4–3 by Scott/Shawn lane with Jacques flipping.
keyMoments: Forms early bonds with Carrie, Spud

players.story: Early Lawa glue with Carrie and Spud; swap/Naale tensions and dislikes cost him.

players.name: Ellody

notes: Clean majority boot 7–3 once Lawa formed structure.
keyMoments: Targeted over Carrie to keep a shield

players.story: Never found solid footing on Lawa; removed as the safe consensus over louder targets.

players.name: Laurie

keyMoments: Extreme conflict with Cody at swap
Wrong side of key pre-merge votes

players.story: Early friction with multiple Lawa members; long-running hostility with Cody; removed at merge to calm tensions.

players.name: Lorenzo
players.story: Survived one swap vote via social bridge to Pete, then fell to the MacArthur/Sky/Tom majority.

players.name: MacArthur

seasonDetails.gameplayStyle: Power-social hybrid; alliance switchboard with intimidation and restraint
keyMoments: Finds Mauhu idol pre-merge and holds it deep
Anchors Mauhu trio and later Lawa #3 with Carrie/Cody
Refuses to pile on Kitty in Ep10, signaling independent agency
Wins merge immunity (Ep12), stabilizes lane targeting Shawn
Burns idol perfectly at F5 advantage dump
Beats Cody and Carrie 6–2–1 at FTC

players.story: Idol-holding enforcer who bridged factions across swaps and merge. Weathered public fights, steered multiple votes, and arrived at FTC with broad respect.

players.name: Pete

notes: Extra Vote from Exile; spent it trying to boot Kitty but got bounced instead.
keyMoments: Pushes anti-Kitty merge vote; uses extra vote

players.story: Exile gainer turned mid-merge swing; lines up the anti-Kitty push but gets nuked by her idol firewall.

players.name: Spud

keyMoments: Argues with Kitty before joint Tribal

players.story: Early chaos archetype who formed real ties (Devin) but got targeted as the ‘easy’ cross-tribe vote.

players.name: Taylor

notes: Idol ricochet casualty at F7 after Tom’s play.
keyMoments: Becomes central hub on Naale pre-merge

players.story: Merge super-connector with unbreakable bonds to Jacques and Carrie; near-constant target of the Scott/Shawn duo; eliminated by redirected votes.

players.name: Tom

notes: Idol ricochet architect at F7; booted at F5 via unanimous pile-on after Vote Steal.
keyMoments: Hangs around as swing through merge
F7 idol play cancels 5 votes and knocks out Taylor
F5 eliminated after Carrie steals his vote

players.story: Stealth endgamer who found merge idol, timed a perfect play to bounce Taylor at F7, then got steamrolled by advantage dump at F5.
